projects.title: Salesforce Internship
projects.overview:
This past summer, I completed my first internship! I had the pleasure of joining Salesforce‚Äôs Global Enablement ‚Äî Tech Ops team as a Visual Experience Design Intern.

Tech Ops built internal technology that helped streamline workplace operations and was working on an online learning platform when I came on board. I supported this project by leading usability testing sessions and utilizing my insights to assist in a UI redesign. I also created brand collateral for this product and provided additional visual communication needs.

blocks.title: Research
blocks.content:
The online learning tool that my team was working on aimed to centralize learning at Salesforce, which involved understanding the needs of 2 users:

  • Enabler (Manager) ‚Äî Creates and assigns learning. Needs to be able to manage their courses + assignments and view the progress of their employees.
  • Learner (Employee) ‚Äî Receives and completes learning. Needs to be able to track their progress, enroll in classes, and receive notifications.

At the time that I had joined the project, the product was in its third release. The lead UX designer on my team had recently left the company, but had completed user testing for the Enabler point of view beforehand. My task was to continue where she had left off and conduct usability testing for the Learner.

I was currently the only designer on Tech Ops, making this an intimidating task. I quickly learned the importance of being a self-starter and reached out to designers from other teams for mentorship. Using their guidance and the recordings + notes that the previous designer had left for me, I created a user testing plan and contacted 6 new hires across various positions for interviews. Afterwards, I synthesized my insights and presented them to my team.

blocks.title: Redesign
blocks.captionBefore:
In between my UX research tasks, I was fortunate enough to explore other areas of interest. A neighboring team of visual designers was working on a redesign of the same product, and I assisted by researching best UI practices and providing feedback.

My usability testing revealed many pain points in our assignment cards, so we were particularly focused on improving how we communicated assignment details, progress, due dates, and time left. I analyzed the card designs used by popular online learning platforms, such as Trailhead üôä, Codecademy, and Treehouse, to discover the best way to organize and display information. As someone interested in both visual and UX, it was exciting to see how these fields intersect to create fluid digital experiences.
blocks.alt: Card designs from Trailhead, Codecademy, and Treehouse
blocks.captionAfter: Additionally, I contributed to the product‚Äôs corporate slide deck by illustrating a few landscapes for custom slide templates. Being able to design under a well-established brand grew my appreciation for the planning and structure that successful brand implementation requires.

blocks.title: Visual Communication
blocks.content: In addition to supporting the upcoming learning tool, I also strengthened my team‚Äôs visual communication by redesigning and building presentation materials. Visual design is often overlooked as a powerful organization tool, especially in business and engineering-oriented settings. By mindfully using design elements to apply visual hierarchy to ordinary or disorganized content, I was able to help my team better communicate their ideas.

blocks.title: Takeaways
blocks.content:
• Actively seek out opportunities and make the most of your internship. My main task was to conduct usability testing, but through coffee chats I connected with designers outside of my team that invited me to do additional work. Because of this, I was able to make deeper contributions, meet more mentors, and explore interests outside of what I was hired for.
  • Continue to grow outside of work. Being from Southern California, San Francisco was a refreshing shift in perspective that helped me understand the world just a little bit better.

Thank you to Gyo, Megan, Matt, and the lovely interns I met along the way.

projects.title: ERGO
projects.overview: Our work environments can work against us. ERGO is a web app that combats the discomfort and injury that results from a sedentary lifestyle by periodically alerting users to stretch. Designed to work across many different spaces, ERGO is unique in that it introduces exercises that use the everyday objects around us, inspiring users to rethink their interactions with their spatial environments.

details.title: Roles
details.content: Led the brand + UI design and development of the HTML prototype. Interaction design was done as a team.

details.title: Key Skills
details.content: Needfinding, storyboarding, wireframing, rapid prototyping, visual design, web development

blocks.title: Design Brief
blocks.content: When the spaces we regularly navigate become a part of our routines, we fail to recognize how we interact with them. Our team's goal was to reassess the interactions between users and their environments to discover how these interactions could be used to fulfill unmet user needs. In particular, we were interested in human behavior within work settings and how the use of computers could contribute to successes and breakdowns.

blocks.title: Needfinding
blocks.captionBefore: We observed 3 participants in their respective work environments and discovered that wellness was a common concern between them. Using the data we collected, we constructed personas that encapsulated our target audience: people who regularly experience long periods of physical inactivity.

blocks.title: Ideation
blocks.content:
To guide us towards a solution, we reframed the insights and pain points above into opportunities:

  • How might we remind users to take breaks and stretch after long intervals of inactivity?
  • How might we accommodate users in different spaces or users with different tools at their disposal?
  • How might we make being active enticing to users?
  • Additionally, how might we accommodate users with disabilities or injuries?

blocks.title: Solution
blocks.content:
Our solution was an ergonomics app that periodically notifies users to perform a stretch or exercise. It would be unique in that it takes into account the user's setting and suggests stretches that are applicable to the devices they're using. These suggestions could then be customized for accessibility and further flexibility. This approach sets the app apart from its competitors by providing users a more fun, personalized stretching experience.

To encourage users to actually perform the stretches provided by the app, we decided to include a social feature. Once a user is done setting up a routine, they could share their settings with their friends or coworkers so that they all receive the same notifications. By turning stretching into a group activity, the app takes advantage of the power of social influence to get users to be more active.

blocks.title: Storyboarding
blocks.alt: Storyboard: Natalie and Robb successfully use ERGO to reduce their respective pains

blocks.title: Rapid Prototyping
blocks.captionBefore: We then created two prototypes and had participants walk through several use cases on each one. Our first prototype (left) starts by asking users what device they're working on, while the second prototype (right) asks users where they are working.
blocks.captionAfter: An issue we discovered while testing was that a user's device does not tell us much about their environment (e.g. a laptop can be used anywhere). So, we decided to move forward with our second prototype. View paper prototypes.

blocks.title: Revisiting the Brief + Redesign
blocks.content:
Upon revisiting the design brief, we realized we had strayed. While our solution provided users with exercises that were relevant for their location and setup, this was not an environmental interaction in itself. So, how might various work spaces be used to help their respective occupants reach their end goals?

Our revised solution was to have our application suggest stretches that use surrounding objects. Environments would be grouped with other environments based on the objects that are common to them. We redefined our categories as follows:

  1. Office ‚Äî possibly a cubicle or small space; stretches can utilize desks and chairs
  2. Home ‚Äî wide array of furniture at user's disposal, disruptive exercises are not a concern
  3. Indoor (public) ‚Äî libraries, coffee shops; stretches are seated and more discreet
  4. Outdoor ‚Äî open space; stretches can utilize larger objects such as trees or poles, exercises can be more extensive (e.g. running)

blocks.title: Wireframing
blocks.alt: App flow when logged in and logged out
blocks.captionBefore: Next, we created wireframes to visualize the flow of our app.

blocks.title: Brand + UI Design
blocks.captionBefore: Our decision to go with a light UI was made carefully after considering that working and studying often take place during the day and in well-lit spaces. We incorporated pops of a vibrant blue-green gradient to set an energizing and refreshing mood that reflects ERGO's main goal: to encourage wellness.

blocks.title: HTML Prototype
blocks.content:
With our app flow and branding established, we were able to start developing our live prototype. With the help of tools such as

  • Node.js (Express + Handlebars)
  • Sass

we built a responsive HTML prototype. Over the next 6 weeks, we implemented core functionalities and refined our app using feedback from users. Check out our live prototype and our Github repository.

blocks.title: User Testing
blocks.alt: Left: New home page with how to get started tips and environment descriptions; Right: New setup page with environment name in the title
blocks.captionBefore: One of the biggest problems we discovered while user testing is that ERGO had poor visibility of system status. To resolve this issue, we made labels more informative and added more descriptions throughout our app.

blocks.alt: New person icon and bookmark icon
blocks.captionBefore: Another problem we had was that users did not find our icons intuitive, namely our Log In and Favorites buttons. We replaced our Log In icon with the universal icon for Profile, a person, and decided to rename our Favorites page to Bookmarks. Stretch routines are saved using URL parameters, so we decided this new title would be more fitting.
blocks.captionAfter: After implementing these changes, we continued user testing and received positive feedback.

blocks.title: Final Design
blocks.content: View our live prototype to check out our final design!

projects.title: Burow
projects.overview: Burow is a desktop web app concept that helps users find the perfect new neighborhood to move to. By reversing the user flow of existing real estate apps and ditching the professional look, Burow provides a unique home hunting experience.

details.title: Teammates
details.content:
Aman Gupta ‚Äî developer
Joel Sequeira ‚Äî developer
Jared Suasin ‚Äî developer, web designer

blocks.title: Problem
blocks.content: Popular real estate apps, such as Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin, start by asking users for a location. Users then use metrics such as price and number of beds/baths to sort through the returned listings. Additional research could then be done to find walkability, safety scores, and more for an address. This user flow works great for those looking for homes in specific neighborhoods, but what if you wanted to choose a neighborhood based on a metric?

blocks.title: Solution
blocks.content:
Our team's solution reversed the user flow of traditional real estate apps to allow users to scan cities at a macro level. It does this by focusing on price, walkability, and school rating, and sorting neighborhoods within a city by these criteria. Because these scores can vary dramatically between neighborhoods, this approach benefits users who know little about their new city.

Existing Solution

Enter location ‚Üí receive listings ‚Üí use criteria to sort through listings

Proposed Solution

Enter city ‚Üí choose criteria ‚Üí receive sorted neighborhoods

blocks.title: Storyboarding
blocks.alt: Mark and Sarah want to move their family from New York to California.
blocks.captionBefore: To better understand our target users, we started by drafting two storyboards.

blocks.alt: Jim is a student looking for an apartment for his internship in the Bay Area this summer.
blocks.captionAfter: Storyboards by Jared and Joel.

blocks.title: Competitive Analysis
blocks.alt: Landing pages of Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin
blocks.captionAfter: Zillow, Trulia, and Redfin all use real estate photos, generous negative space, and safe typefaces to create a clean, polished look. While a professional appearance increases credibility, it comes with the tradeoff of looking impersonal and detached.

blocks.title: Brand Design
blocks.captionBefore:
"Burow‚ÄîDig around and find the neighbourhood that fits your needs!"

Since our app only sorts neighborhoods and does not show listings or collect any personal data, we could afford to forgo the professional look. So, we took the opposite approach and used the theme of cute, burrowing animals to establish a cozy and welcoming atmosphere. Because Burow‚Äôs search functionality centers around neighborhoods instead of individual homes, the animals also serve to reflect community.

To produce a homey feel, we gravitated towards warm earth tones and typefaces with gentle curves. We kept our illustrations soft as well and made heavy use of geometric shapes to instill a sense of familiarity. UI elements were also rounded to support the warm brand.

projects.title: Digitizing the Red Envelope Experience
projects.description: A reimagination of the digital red envelope.
projects.overview:
This past Lunar New Year, over 800 million red envelopes were sent and received digitally. While being able to exchange envelopes virtually is convenient, existing solutions are heavily gamified, detracting from the cultural focus that physical red envelope exchanges hold. I evaluated these solutions and surveyed Lunar New Year celebrants to discover how to translate the cultural aspects of the red envelope exchange into the user experience.

This project was inspired by my own experiences as a Vietnamese American. Ch√∫c m·ª´ng nƒÉm m·ªõi! üßß

Note: work in progress.

blocks.title: What is a Red Envelope?
blocks.content: Red envelopes are small, decorative packets that are gifted to friends and family during special occasions and holidays. The color red symbolizes good luck in Chinese and other East Asian cultures. The envelopes usually contain clean, crisp cash and are most commonly presented on Lunar New Year by elders to the younger.

blocks.title: Problem
blocks.content: Unfortunately, not everyone can spend the holidays with their friends and family. Online payment services make it easy to send money, but the cultural significance of the red envelope is lost. Lunar New Year celebrants need a way to digitally exchange red envelopes so that they can celebrate their culture with loved ones who are far away.

blocks.title: Current Solution
blocks.content:
In 2014, the massive Chinese messaging and mobile payment platform WeChat introduced a feature that allows users to send and receive virtual red envelopes. Several competing tech companies began rolling out similar functions. While these services solve our problem at a glance, I observed several major pain points of WeChat‚Äôs red packet feature:

1. Too big of an emphasis placed on cash-based incentives.

Cash incentives and gamification have caused virtual red envelope services to be met with criticism for turning the tradition into a monetary venture. Examples include:

  • Users can send packets to groups and randomize the amounts in each envelope. In stark contrast, the amount of money in physical red envelopes is often chosen intentionally based on cultural beliefs.
  • In 2014, a popular Chinese New Year special used WeChat‚Äôs red packets to give away over $80 million to its viewers. Users would shake their phones for a chance to win red envelopes.

Additionally, the gamification of the red envelope exchange has turned it into an impersonal process, encouraging users to receive money from strangers. This makes users more suspect to fraud. Incidents have been reported of users falling for phishing attacks while ‚Äúreceiving‚Äù envelopes, hosting fake giveaways to gain followers, and more.

2. Too similar to other mobile payment services.

Underneath the themed interface, WeChat‚Äôs red packet feature functions exactly like Venmo, Cash App, and co. Users enter the amount they‚Äôd like to send, add a message to go along with it, and then confirm. The red + gold design and inclusion of envelope illustrations are the only aspects of the service that translate culture.

3. Can only exchange between WeChat users.

WeChat and its competitors have a predominantly Chinese user base, leaving a gap in the market. For 89% of the world, WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger are the most popular messaging apps.

blocks.title: New Solution
blocks.content: For my app concept, my main goal was to preserve the culture held in the physical red envelope experience. I planned to minimize the amount of cash incentives + gamification involved, introduce new features to help translate traditions, and craft a unique brand identity. Since my solution is a standalone app, it would be able to serve users coming from multiple messaging platforms.

blocks.title: Research
blocks.content:
To discover how to bring more cultural elements into the app's experience, I interviewed 8 (fun fact: this is the Chinese lucky number) celebrants who partook in red envelope exchange. Participants were aged between 19 and 58, and my questions focused on the role red envelopes played in their celebrations. Main takeaways:

All said receiving/gifting an envelope involved a customary expression of gratitude.

  • Wishing the other person luck + prosperity
  • Giving a personal message
  • Bowing your head

7 said they‚Äôve spent a New Years away from home.

6 of these 7 have had envelopes left for them to open when they returned home or had left envelopes for others.
4 of these 7 have used a payment service to send/receive money in place of an envelope.

7 felt that the red envelopes were an important part of their celebration.

4 felt that the red envelopes were more significant than the cash inside.

‚ÄúI think [red envelopes] are really symbolic of prosperity and respect.‚Äù

From my research, it was clear that users valued the red envelope itself. I kept this in mind moving forward.

blocks.title: Research
blocks.content:
To discover how to bring more cultural elements into the app's experience, I interviewed 8 (fun fact: this is the Chinese lucky number) celebrants who partook in red envelope exchange. Participants were aged between 19 and 58, and my questions focused on the role red envelopes played in their celebrations. Main takeaways:

  1. All said receiving/gifting an envelope involved a customary expression of gratitude. Namely:
    • Wishing the other person luck + prosperity
    • Giving a personal message
    • Bowing your head
  2. 7 said they‚Äôve spent a New Years away from home.
    • 6 of these 7 have had envelopes left for them to open when they returned home or had left envelopes for others.
    • 4 of these 7 have used a payment service to send/receive money in place of an envelope.
  3. 7 felt that the red envelopes were an important part of their celebration.
  4. 4 felt that the red envelopes were more significant than the cash inside.
    • ‚ÄúI think [red envelopes] are really symbolic of prosperity and respect.‚Äù

From my research, it was clear that users valued the red envelope itself. I kept this in mind moving forward.

blocks.title: Main Features
blocks.content:
Using my research insights, I decided on the following main features:

  • Add ability to send photo/video messages ‚Äî Allows users to send more personalized messages and show actions (e.g. bowing).
  • Remove ability to send envelopes to groups ‚Äî 1:1 transactions closer simulate the in-person experience.
  • Custom envelopes ‚Äî Allows senders to choose from a variety of red envelope designs or scan a physical envelope.
  • Interactive envelope prep ‚Äî Users will have to slide on-screen cash into an on-screen envelope. This process for gifting money further simulates the in-person experience while hindering ingenuine transactions.

blocks.title: Soft Rebrand
blocks.content:
During my term as a visual and brand designer, my co and I introduced a new, illustration-heavy creative direction that refreshed the face of Design at UCSD.

Problem

While crafting graphics for the org, we quickly noted a few flaws in our visual system that inspired us to rethink the branding guidelines surrounding our marketing visuals. The existing system for creating event banners involved placing color overlays over photos, with each color representing a different event type:

  • Yellow ‚Äî industry events
  • Red ‚Äî social events
  • Green ‚Äî design skill workshops
  • Blue ‚Äî data + research workshops

blocks.captionAfter:
Major issues we ran into included:

  • Visual style was outdated and limited creativity. Design at UCSD is a community of young, eager designers, and we wanted a fun and contemporary look to reflect this.
  • Our event type distribution was too unbalanced to justify using a color-based system. Over the course of the 2017‚Äì2018 school year, Design at UCSD held 13 design skill workshops, 9 social events, 6 industry events, and only 1 data + research workshop.
  • Banners were not unique to each event. Social media is fast-paced, and more interest could be generated by using eye-catching visuals.

blocks.captionBefore:
Solution

To reflect current design trends and craft a unique identity for each event, we decided to retire the color-based system and start creating dedicated illustrations for each banner. We used a flat design style and incorporated derivations of our original 4 colors to stay on-brand.
blocks.captionAfter: Shout-out to Nancy, Lauren, and Lucy.

blocks.alt: Side-by-side comparison of a Facebook event from Jan 2018 and the same event from Jan 2019, showing an increase in interest
blocks.captionBefore: Our soft rebrand was received positively by our leadership board and Design at UCSD saw an increase in online member engagement.
